description.narrative: With 91 labs supporting 115 countries across the globe, the project seeks to tackle the complexity of development by introducing new protocols, backed by evidence and practice, testing and dissemination of solutions within and across countries.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output: 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Network have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

Output 1: 2 new data sources used at Country Office level.
3 Diversity of different data sources used
20 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented
2 Varieties of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: 2 blogs, videos, or other (substantial) media posts as learnings the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP)
1 lab insights, process or product which are taken up by government or other partners.
1% of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite
1% Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: Each lab should interact at least once a week with another lab, a partner, and the global team as a way of tracking the size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs
2% of information shared on different platforms shows the new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network.
2% monthly increase in engagement on Twitter. 2% monthly increase in Twitter and LinkedIn followers. 100+ impressions on Twitter. 100 views per month for blogs as tracking the engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network.
1% of the conversation will be influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network to track the amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Network have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

Output 1: 5new data sources were used at Country Office level. Crowdsourcing, citizens data, Ethnography, Collective Intelligence and GIS
5Diversity of different data sources were used. Crowdsourcing, citizens data, Ethnography, Collective Intelligence and GIS
152 Number of sustainable development solutions were identified and documented
3 Varieties of innovation methods were used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. E-commerce platform to connect informal market vendors online, Transforming Mulago Hospital Kitchen from using biomass to electricity as an experiment to test the affordability and efficiency of electricity as an alternative cooking solution to biomass in a bid curb deforestation and lastly Youth Ideathon to empower and train youth with viable entrepreneurial ideas to tackle youth unemployment.
Output 2: 12 blogs, 2 videos, and 25 other (substantial) media posts as learnings the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP)
2 lab insights, process or products were taken up by government entities. One is the Natural Resource Information System (NARIS) was taken up for scaling by National Forests Authority (NFA) and National Environment Management Authority (NEMA) for natural resource governance. The second is the the use of Electricity as an alternative solution for cooking was taken up by Mulago National Referral Hospital. This led to policy change where the Electricity Regulatory Authority (ERA) reduced the electricity tariff rate from UGX 556 per Kwh to UGX 451.4per Kwh for large institutions in Uganda.
10% of partners and government increased their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite. NARIS was taken up for scaling by government bodies like the National Forestry Authority (NFA), National Environment Management Authority (NEMA) with support from the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (SIDA) and Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (NORAD) through the UNDP Anti-Corruption for Peaceful and Inclusive Societies (ACPIS) Global Programme.
50% Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming (5 flagship programmes) was influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies. This was mainly through the supporting of the Country Programme Document (CPD)
Output 3: Each lab member interacted more than once a week with another lab, a partner, and the global team tracking the size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs using the different platforms like WhatsApp, Zoom weekly global call, meetings with different partners e.t.c
10%of information shared on different platforms showed new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network.
5% monthly increase in engagement on Twitter. 5% monthly increase in Twitter and LinkedIn followers. 2000+ impressions on Twitter. 200 views per month for blogs were recorded as tracking the engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network.
7% of the conversation was influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network to track the amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Network have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.
